content: The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" prohibits stigmatization of children unable to pay for meals. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" amends Section 9(b)(10) of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act to prevent discriminatory or stigmatizing treatment of children by schools based on eligibility or lack of funds. It defines a "covered child" as a student at a school participating in the school lunch program. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" aims to prevent schools from treating children unfairly based on their eligibility or lack of funds for school meals. It includes provisions for students who cannot afford lunch or breakfast at school, ensuring they are not stigmatized or discriminated against. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" prohibits school food authorities from publicly identifying or stigmatizing covered children, such as by requiring them to wear wristbands or display hand stamps. It also prohibits any requirements that would stigmatize covered children based on their status. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" prohibits students from being tasked with extra chores or disposing of meals after they have been served. A school food authority must direct communications regarding outstanding credits for a covered child to the parent or guardian, not the child. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" prohibits stigmatizing a covered child by requiring them to deliver a letter to their parent or guardian containing communication about outstanding credits. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" aims to ensure that free or reduced-price lunch applications are distributed in a clear format and with assistance provided to parents. School authorities must also coordinate with agencies to support homeless children. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" requires school authorities to ensure that homeless children and foster children eligible for free lunches and breakfasts receive them. The "Anti-Lunch Shaming Act of 2017" mandates that school food authorities participating in the school lunch or breakfast programs must provide meals to children regardless of their ability to pay or outstanding balances. They are also required to offer the same meal options to all students and encouraged to find innovative ways to address meal affordability.
